review.title: Using Incomplete Information for Complete Weight Annotation of Road Networks -- Extended Version
review.abstract: We are witnessing increasing interests in the effective use of road networks. For example, to enable effective vehicle routing, weighted-graph models of transportation networks are used, where the weight of an edge captures some cost associated with traversing the edge, e.g., greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions or travel time. It is a precondition to using a graph model for routing that all edges have weights. Weights that capture travel times and GHG emissions can be extracted from GPS trajectory data collected from the network. However, GPS trajectory data typically lack the coverage needed to assign weights to all edges. This paper formulates and addresses the problem of annotating all edges in a road network with travel cost based weights from a set of trips in the network that cover only a small fraction of the edges, each with an associated ground-truth travel cost. A general framework is proposed to solve the problem. Specifically, the problem is modeled as a regression problem and solved by minimizing a judiciously designed objective function that takes into account the topology of the road network. In particular, the use of weighted PageRank values of edges is explored for assigning appropriate weights to all edges, and the property of directional adjacency of edges is also taken into account to assign weights. Empirical studies with weights capturing travel time and GHG emissions on two road networks (Skagen, Denmark, and North Jutland, Denmark) offer insight into the design properties of the proposed techniques and offer evidence that the techniques are effective.
histories: This is an extended version of "Using Incomplete Information for Complete Weight Annotation of Road Networks," which is accepted for publication in IEEE TKDE

sections.heading: 3.2 Trips and Trip Costs
sections.text: Since vehicle tracking using GPS is widespread and continues to grow, we take into account routes derived from GPS observations. A GPS trajectory gpsT r = (gps1, gps2,.., gpsn) is a sequence of GPS observations in which a GPS observation gpsi indicates the location of a vehicle at a given time. After map matching and some pre-processing, a GPS trajectory is converted into a journey t = (l1, l2,., lm) consisting of a sequence of link records li of the form: link record li: (e, ts, te), in which e-E indicates an edge in G and ts and te indicates the time points of the first and last GPS observations at the edge ei. sections.text: Since we consider the problem to be a regression problem, we will discuss the design of the proposed objective function and the solution to minimize the objective function.

sections.heading: 4.2 Topological Constraint
sections.text: The topology of a road network is highly correlated with human movement [20], [21] including movement of pedestrians and vehicles. Edges with similar movement currents can have similar cost variables. Thus, if an edge in TC is covered, its cost-variable information can be transmitted to edges with similar movement currents. To this end, we are investigating how the movement currents can be quantified using the topological information of road networks.

sections.heading: 4.3 Adjacency Constraint
sections.text: The PRTC function is derived from the overall structure of the road network. In this section, we will consider a fine-grained topological aspect of the road network, namely the direct connection. An important characteristic of a road network is that an event on a road section may have an impact on adjacent road segments. Let us consider a typical event (B, C) as an example of congestion (B, C), or at least traffic on (B, C) is affected by the traffic volume that occurs on a road segment (A, B). If there is congestion on on a road segment (A, B) in Fig. 2, the road segment (B, C) may also experience congestion, or at least traffic on the (B, C). Thus, the cost variables of two directionally adjacent road segments are similar.

sections.heading: 4.4 Solving The Problem
sections.text: By combining the three individual objective functions and a classical L2 regulator, we obtain the general objective function O (d): O (d) = RSS (d) + α · PRTC (d) + β · DATC (d) + γ · | d | | 22, where α, β and γ are hyperparameters controlling the compromise between losses on RSS, PRTC, DATC and the L2 regulator. sections.heading: 4.5 Discussion
sections.text: In addition to the topology of a road network, other aspects of edges can be useful for identifying similarities between edges, such as the shapes and capacities of edges and the interesting points along the edges. [34] Such information is not always available in digital maps and can be difficult to obtain. However, it is of interest to expand the proposed methods to take additional information into account when available. In order to achieve a general applicability of the paper methods, we minimize the requirements of the input graph G ′: both PRTC and DATC rely exclusively on the topology of a road network, which can be easily obtained from any digital map. Finally, the problem of weight annotation is solved by solving a system of linear equations, i.e. Equation 12. Alternative edge similarity metrics (i.e. taking into account the shapes and capacities of edges) can be easily integrated into the linear system by adding new terms of shape, the LM.

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTAL STUDY
sections.text: We are investigating the effectiveness of the proposed method for indicating the weight of road networks with both travel time (TTWA) and greenhouse gas emissions (GEWA).

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: It is only a matter of time before that happens, that it happens.

sections.heading: 5.2 Experimental Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Effectiveness Measurements
sections.text: In order to gain insight into the accuracy of the costs obtained based on the actual costs, we divide the set of (travel, cost) emissions (travel, cost) pairs into a training set TCtrain and a test set TCtest. We use the training set to comment on the spatial network of weights, and we use the test set to evaluate the accuracy of the weights obtained. In the following experiments, we randomly select 50% of the pairs for training and the remaining 50% for testing, unless it is explicitly stated otherwise. Since there are no time-dependent weights for the two road networks, the accuracy of the weights obtained can only be evaluated using the TCtest set TCtest. If the weights obtained (with TCtrain) actually reflect the difference between the actual costs and the estimated costs by using the weights obtained (i.e. by defining Equation 1, which is defined in Section 3.2) in the test set for each trip.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Travel Time Based Weight Annotation
sections.text: The effectiveness of objective functions: Table 5 reports the results based on weight annotation. Column SSLF1 reports the absolute SSL values for all test drives when objective function F1 is used for both sets of data. NJ has much higher SSL values than SK because there are many more test drives. However, for both road networks, the weights annotated with objective function F4 are the least SSL values. We also observe that the PageRank-based topological restrictions work more effectively on NJ than on SK. This is because Scagen is a small town where few street segments have a similar topology (e.g., similarly weighted PageRank values). In the NJ network, the topological restriction is based on better accuracy as more road segments have similarly weighted PageRank values. Reporting in Table 6 also justifies observation.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 GHG Emissions Based Weight Annotation
sections.text: Effectiveness of objective functions: Table 8 shows the results of the weight remark based on GHG emissions. In general, the results are consistent with the results of the time-based weight remark (as shown in Table 5): (i) The PageRank-based topological restraint works more effectively on the NJ network than on the SK network; (ii) the weights obtained by using PRTC and DATC give the best accuracy. The coverage when using the various objective functions is exactly the same as that in Table 6. Comparison with a baseline: As with driving times, we use speed restraints to develop a base limit for GHG emissions based on weight remark. Assuming that a vehicle is driving on an edge at constant speed (e.g. the speed limit of edge x), we can simulate a sequence of the speed remark.

sections.heading: 5.2.4 Effectiveness of the Size of Training Trips
sections.text: In this section, we will examine the accuracy of variation in training size. Specifically, in the NJ network, we reserve 20% of the (travel, cost) pairs as a test set, called the TCtest, and the remaining 80% as a training set, called the TCtrain. To observe the accuracy of the weight specification for various sizes of the TCtrain, we use 100%, 80%, 60%, 40%, and 20% of the TCtrain, respectively, to comment on the weights. Results are shown in Figure 11.For the travel time, when only 20% of the TCtrain is used, the accuracy of our method is worse than that of the base method with λ = 1, as the base method has a rough estimate of the cost of all edges, while the 20% of the TCtrain only covers 16.3% of the edges on the road network. Although our method propagates weights to edges not covered by the training trips, the accuracy suffers if the initial coverage of the training method is twice as high as the 40% when the emissions are almost lower.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION AND OUTLOOK
sections.text: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport requires an effective eco-routing method, and road network diagrams in which all edges are provided with accurate weights that capture environmental costs, such as fuel consumption or greenhouse gas emissions, are required for an eco-routing method. However, such weights are not always readily available for a road network. This paper proposes a general framework that takes a measurement of (travel, cost) pairs as a starting point and assigns travel cost-based weights to a chart that represents a road network in which travel cost-based weights can reflect GHG emissions, fuel consumption or travel time. Using this framework, edge weights that capture environmental impacts can be calculated for the entire road network, enabling eco-routing. To the best of knowledge, this is the first work that provides a general framework for allocating travel cost-based edge weights based on a set of (cost - two directions) of future work.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

metadata.abstractText: We are witnessing increasing interests in the effective use of road networks. For example, to enable effective vehicle routing, weighted-graph models of transportation networks are used, where the weight of an edge captures some cost associated with traversing the edge, e.g., greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions or travel time. It is a precondition to using a graph model for routing that all edges have weights. Weights that capture travel times and GHG emissions can be extracted from GPS trajectory data collected from the network. However, GPS trajectory data typically lack the coverage needed to assign weights to all edges. This paper formulates and addresses the problem of annotating all edges in a road network with travel cost based weights from a set of trips in the network that cover only a small fraction of the edges, each with an associated ground-truth travel cost. A general framework is proposed to solve the problem. Specifically, the problem is modeled as a regression problem and solved by minimizing a judiciously designed objective function that takes into account the topology of the road network. In particular, the use of weighted PageRank values of edges is explored for assigning appropriate weights to all edges, and the property of directional adjacency of edges is also taken into account to assign weights. Empirical studies with weights capturing travel time and GHG emissions on two road networks (Skagen, Denmark, and North Jutland, Denmark) offer insight into the design properties of the proposed techniques and offer evidence that the techniques are effective. This is an extended version of “Using Incomplete Information for Complete Weight Annotation of Road Networks” [1], which is accepted for publication in IEEE TKDE.
